reviewText: Even though Eleanor Powell gets top billing in LADY BE GOOD, this 1941 MGM musical actually focuses on the tumultuous, up-and-down marriage and career of Dixie Donegan (Ann Sothern) and Eddie Crane (Robert Young), that fictional songwriting duo that had a heyday during the tin pan alley period. Dixie is the lyricist; Eddie provides the melody. Powell plays Dixie's best friend, hoofer Marilyn Marsh, who schemes to reunite the squabbling couple. LADY BE GOOD was very loosely adapted from the original 1924 stage version which starred Fred Astaire and his sister Adele. And when I say "very loosely adapted," I mean that the entire storyline was overhauled and only two of the songs retained ("Lady Be Good" and "Fascinating Rhythm").I shouldn't be surprised that Ann Sothern can sing some. An actor, back in the day, flaunted a seriously diverse skills set. He had to be well-versed not only with reciting dialogue but as well with horse-riding, sword-fighting, and song and dance. I've no doubt that if you were to put Ann Sothern on a horse and hand her a rapier, she'd vault a fence and parry the closest Musketeer. Or maybe I'm exaggerating. Anyway, her vocal talents are on display as she sings several songs in LADY BE GOOD, one of which is a highlight performance ("The Last Time I Saw Paris") and the other involves a sequence at the film's start in which Sothern and Young's characters first collaborate on a song. Their neat torch song rendition of "You'll Never Know" made me sit up and take notice. And then, to my delight, they rapidly took the song and performed a swing version of it.The story itself is silly and left me shaking my head at Sothern and Young's silly antics. She believes that they're more productive as a songwriting team when they're not married. He's the jealous type. The plot gets pretty old, even though it features supporting bits from Red Skelton (as Dixie and Eddie's song promoter), Tom Conway (as Dixie's divorce lawyer), John Carroll (as a crooner and Eddie's perceived rival), and Lionel Barrymore (as the judge). Luckily, Eleanor Powell rights the ship some with two showstopping dance numbers. One is her elaborate segment in the extended, Busby Berkeley-directed "Fascinating Rhythm" sequence which featured a series of grand pianos and a hundred nattily-attired male dancers sporting canes. But better than that is her marvelous duet with a dog that she apparently had trained herself for that very number.The three very acrobatic, dancing Berry Brothers are worth a peek. Virginia O'Brien has a small part and sings a song or two. Virginia O'Brien, as you know, when she sings, is so deliberately deadpan, she makes Keely Smith seem positively animated.Jerome Kern and Oscar Hammerstein II's "The Last Time I Saw Paris" won the Oscar for Best Song for LADY BE GOOD, never mind that the song had already been around for ages. Anyway, this film is recommended for the Gershwin-Kern-Hammerstein musical interludes. The screwball stuff comes off as mildly amusing, and I'm being generous.

reviewText: 4 1/2 starsLady Be Good is a notable MGM musical with a fine plot that moves along well, excellent song and dance numbers and a background musical score that enhances the film as well! The choreography and the cinematography both shine with Busby Berkeley's direction of the musical numbers showing great forethought (Norman Z. McLeod directed the rest of the film). The use of light and camera angles made the most emotional and sentimental scenes quite memorable such as when Ann Sothern's character, Dixie Donegan Crane, sings "The Last Time I Saw Paris" (which is also historically significant since the Germans had invaded France not all that long before this film was released), when Eleanor Powell dances superbly with her pet dog as well as the stunning scene in which The Berry Brothers dance up a storm! True, the film has a few embarrassingly dated moments with stereotypes of Asians and African-Americans dancing and singing to "Lady Be Good;" but overall the film remains one of MGM's better musicals.When the action starts, we meet the principle characters of the plot. Dixie Crane, a lyricist, wants a divorce from her composer husband Eddie Crane (Robert Young) essentially because the love has gone out of their marriage; her husband Eddie is no longer the "regular" guy he used to be and hangs out with people she feels are fair-weather friends. Judge Murdock (Lionel Barrymore) grants the divorce after hearing all the testimony including the statements of Dixie's good friend Marilyn Marsh (Eleanor Powell). Marilyn lets Dixie move in with her; Dixie goes back to using her maiden name and we also meet their acquaintances crooner Buddy Crawford (John Carroll); Joe "Red" Willet ("Red" Skelton) and the manager/producer/promoter for Dixie and Eddie's work as a songwriting team, Max Milton (Reginald Owen).Although Dixie and Eddie go their separate ways Eddie still wants to work with her on writing songs just like when they were married. Dixie consents and they do write songs enjoying a particularly big hit with "Lady Be Good" which shoots up the charts and gets recorded by Buddy who is always singing their wonderful songs. However, while their professional relationship becomes quite positive again, they don't see eye to eye about something--Eddie wants to remarry but Dixie doesn't. Marilyn, however, cooks up a plan that she hopes will resolve this conflict and have the couple remarried in a flash.There's more to the plot than this and I'll stop here so you can watch and enjoy this film as much as I did! The rest of the film shows how all of the issues work out.Look also for solid performances by Virginia O'Brien as "Red's" girlfriend Lull; Dan Dailey, Jr. as Bill "Billy" Pattison and Connie Russell is a singer in the "Fascinating Rhythm" production number which includes Six Hits and a Miss as well as Harvey Karels and Charles Teske. Phil Silvers plays a Master of Ceremonies in a nightclub.Lady Be Good will remain one of MGM's better musicals from the early 1940s just before the United States entered World War Two and when this type of somewhat escapist fare was still in demand partially because The Great Depression hadn't completely ended yet and the dark days of World War Two were still in far away countries. I highly recommend this film for fans of the actors in it and people who appreciate movie musicals with romance and some drama thrown in for a good effect will not be disappointed.
summary: "What a spot to be in--a woman who doesn't dare marry her own husband!"

reviewText: Everyone in this movie is terrific, and the story, about the humorously tempestuous relationship of a songwriting couple played by Ann Sothern and Robert Young, is one of the better ones among musicals of the period. The songs and dances are great, too, with two of the high points being Sothern's "The Last Time I Saw Paris" and Eleanor Powell's dancing finale. But most amazing of all is Powell's duet with her dog. This number should be rated along with Fred Astaire's dance on the ceiling in "Royal Wedding" and Donald O'Connor's "Make 'Em Laugh" as one of the best of all time. If you're looking for social commentary, turn on NPR. If you want something deep, find a stable and pick up a shovel. This movie was meant to be fun and entertaining, and it succeeds perfectly.
summary: A Lot of Fun and Great Musical Numbers
